title: Physics Experiment Microlearning Course to Enhance Scientific Inquiry Skills Based on Flipped Learning

context.prior_knowledge: Basic university-level physics theory, laboratory equipment usage experience, and foundational understanding of the scientific inquiry process
context.additional_context: Primarily targeting first-year electrical and electronics engineering students, this flipped learning model systematically develops experimental design and analysis skills. It provides a spacetime-unbound learning environment using digital devices and incorporates collaborative learning and peer assessment systems reflecting socioconstructivist approaches.

learning_goals: After pre-learning experimental procedure videos and materials, achieve ≥80% proficiency in variable control and data collection/interpretation skills in the lab.
Improve experimental error analysis and scientific evidence-based report writing through peer discussions and formative assessments.

In a flipped learning environment, learners form teams of 3–4 members and: (1) analyze two provided videos and one reading to draft an experimental design document (including 1 research question, 2 hypotheses, and a 3-step experimental method specifying independent/dependent/controlled variables), (2) negotiate role assignments (leader, data collector, analyst, presenter), conduct the experiment within two weeks, and collect ≥10 qualitative/quantitative data points, (3) achieve ≥4/5 in peer evaluation (teamwork) and ≥8/10 in instructor evaluation (experimental design rubric), totaling ≥12/15 points.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
